How to find the perfect board member? Build trust!

Iâ€™ve recently become a Board Member at Social Standards, an amazing start up in social media analytics based in Oakland. To make a long story short, they rock! (as this picture shows).

Yes, they were introduced to me by famous business angels that I respect and admire and they were also serial entrepreneurs, but they convinced me about their ambition, how they could help brands to better engage with their customers and improve their performance, while listening to user generated content (on Twitter and Instagram) and transforming insights into actions. And this, vertical after vertical, scaling fast.

I had their demo during two hours: their platform and data solution showed amazing results that I could read on the beauty industry where I have twenty years of expertise: whether at a brand level, or a product one. So we finished the meeting with three boards covered by colorful sketches about the ecosystem and who were decision makers in the companies as potential customers they were pitching (CMOs to the Head of Sales or VP of e commerce).

When I met them for the first time, I also had in mind a few introductions I could do at the relevant time to help them grow their business.

I guess on their side, they concluded I knew the market (and other potential ones in consumer goods), understood the big platforms which were my partners when a C-level executive, and could help them better define their competitive advantage. I had also the operating experience, at ease with processes and management, which could help them to learn more about who they were pitching to generate revenues.

Perfect fit, perfect timing. I quickly met their Board members and investors in a meeting, and we checked together we could build a great team dynamic, able to disagree in a healthy way and find ways to move forward. And that was it!

WHEN SCALING GLOBALLY: MANAGEMENT AND PROCESSES ARE PRIORITIES. #CULTURE

Guidance and a sense of perspective are valuable assets in growth period.

When you grow fast, complexity becomes the issue, and keeping things simple the challenge.

The faster you grow, the more important it is to recruit the best executives, and improve processes.

Choosing a Board Member having an experience in a corporation can help you on different sides:

- managing complexity is part of the job of an executive, able to work well with his peers, building cross functional teams (to avoid silos)

- managing a team, making sure ambition and goals are clearly communicated and people participate

- improving governance and processes depending on the context

Having someone with experience and independent in your Board can help save time and energy.

An independent advisor is not obsessed by metrics and ROI as could be a VC or Investor (shareholders, who are in their roles of making sure the company is on the path to success). He or she is like a mentor, a coach. Having time for the Board meetings but also for a call on specific topics if needed. Providing guidance.

What Iâ€™ve learnt being an Independent Board Member when a company generates hundred Million of revenues?

Growing fast and generating revenues is the period of important decisions (partnerships, alliances, M&A), and sometimes unfortunately crisis communication.

Founding teams need to prepare their key milestones, and be ready for any bad news. Itâ€™s also the period when things must be organized. But first and foremost, itâ€™s about taking care about the culture of the company.

Only people matter.

Itâ€™s true for companies based in Europe or in the Silicon Valley, whether dealing with customers that undergo digital transformations, or being a new player in the emerging tech trends.

People are what makes the culture of the company, from the Founders to the executive team (as they are role models), to each employee and partner.

The biggest challenge when you grow is to keep your culture, consistent at every level, and wherever the employees work.

The Big Difference Iâ€™ve seen is always execution. And in execution, having an Independent (an experienced) Board Member, can help you ask yourself candid questions, be consistent in your messages and listen to peopleâ€™s input.

People need to feel part of a team, participating to a great adventure. Your story is their story.

If they feel confident about the future (and their future), it will help your company to be even more performing and continue to grow.

And by the way, Board Members must also feel engaged. Keeping them informed (call, mails) between two boards without them asking is a good way to be pro-active.

Being and Independent Board Member is also time consuming.

cc Groupama Team France

When I had the honor to sit in the Board room for Groupama (leading European insurance, 14 million premium income, 35000 employees), I had committees to prepare and to attend to. Whether audit committee or compensation & talent one, they need a lot of work to prepare. Being a Board Member means at least ten to twenty meetings per year, so make sure before that your boss accepts it (if an Executive in a corporation) understanding it also helps you to be better in your own job, or you keep time for it as an individual.

In a Public Company Board, you spend a lot of time on the financial reports, and making sure you respect the continuously evolving regulation. So, you need to be a good listener before raising your voice. Iâ€™m grateful to the team to have taught me the industry metrics and financial culture.
